name: Systems Thinking
description: Holistic approach to understanding complex problems by analyzing interconnections, patterns, and system dynamics

structure.name: System Boundaries
structure.description: Define what's inside and outside the system being analyzed

structure.name: Key Components
structure.description: Identify the major elements, actors, and resources in the system

structure.name: Relationships and Interconnections
structure.description: Map how components interact and influence each other

structure.name: Feedback Loops
structure.description: Identify reinforcing and balancing feedback loops that drive system behavior

structure.name: Leverage Points
structure.description: Find points where small changes can create significant system improvements

prompts: What are the boundaries of this system? What's included and excluded?
Who are the key actors, and what are their roles and motivations?
How do different parts of the system influence each other?
What feedback loops exist that reinforce or balance system behavior?
Where are the leverage points that could create disproportionate impact?
What patterns emerge when we look at the system as a whole?
How might changes in one area affect the entire system?
when_to_use: Analyzing ecosystem dynamics and market structures
Understanding root causes of persistent issues
Designing interventions that account for system complexity
Solving wicked problems with many interrelated factors
when_not_to_use: Simple, linear problems with clear cause and effect
Highly technical problems with well-defined parameters
Situations where quick fixes are more important than deep understanding

examples.title: Organizational Culture Change
examples.description: Using systems thinking to understand how cultural patterns reinforce each other and identify intervention points

examples.title: Supply Chain Optimization
examples.description: Analyzing how supply chain disruptions create cascading effects across the entire business system

examples.title: Digital Transformation Strategy
examples.description: Mapping how technology changes create feedback loops affecting business processes and customer behavior

metadata.author: Peter Senge and Systems Thinking Community

validation_status.validation_notes: Fundamental methodology for understanding complexity in business, policy, and social systems

prerequisites: Ability to see the bigger picture beyond immediate issues
Patience for deep analysis without rushing to solutions
Understanding of cause and effect relationships
